definition: Abatement.
example: The word abate is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: A person or object that deviates from the rest of a group.
example: The word aberrant is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: To regard with horror or detestation; to shrink back with shuddering from; to feel excessive repugnance toward; to detest to extremity; to loathe.
example: I absolutely abhor being stuck in traffic jams

definition: A person in the lowest and most despicable condition; a castaway; outcast.
example: The word abject is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: To renounce upon oath; to forswear; to disavow.
example: To abjure allegiance to a prince.

definition: To deny (oneself something); to renounce or give up (a right, a power, a claim, a privilege, a convenience).
example: The word abnegate is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: A substance or material such as sandpaper, pumice, or emery, used for cleaning, smoothing, or polishing.
example: The word abrasive is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: To deprive; to cut off.
example: The word abridge is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: To annul by an authoritative act; to abolish by the authority of the maker or her or his successor; to repeal; — applied to the repeal of laws, decrees, ordinances, the abolition of customs, etc.
example: The word abrogate is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: To flee, often secretly; to steal away, particularly to avoid arrest or prosecution.
example: The thieves absconded with our property.

definition: To set free, release or discharge (from obligations, debts, responsibility etc.).
example: You will absolve a subject from his allegiance.

definition: Keep or withhold oneself.
example: The word abstain is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: An abridgement or summary of a longer publication.
example: The word abstract is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Difficult to comprehend or understand.
example: The word abstruse is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Fully sufficient; found in copious supply; in great quantity; overflowing.
example: [W]ith their magical words they [poets] bring forth to our eyesight the abundant images and beauties of creation. — Leigh Hunt, On the Realities of Imagination

definition: To approach; to arrive, to come forward.
example: The word accede is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: To pronounce with an accent or vocal stress.
example: The word accentuate is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: To shout; to call out.
example: The word acclaim is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: An expression of approval; praise.
example: The word accolade is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: (with in (or sometimes with, to)) To rest satisfied, or apparently satisfied, or to rest without opposition and discontent (usually implying previous opposition or discontent); to accept or consent by silence or by omitting to object.
example: The word acquiesce is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Sharp and harsh, or bitter and not to the taste.
example: Sodium polyacrylate is an acrid salt.

definition: A sharp and bitter hatred.
example: Her acrimony for her neighbors manifests itself with shouting and stomping.

definition: Quickness of perception or discernment; penetration of mind; the faculty of nice discrimination.
example: The word acumen is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: A person who has the acute form of a disorder, such as schizophrenia.
example: The word acute is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: An imaginary rock or mineral of impenetrable hardness; a name given to the diamond and other substances of extreme hardness.
example: The word adamant is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: One fully skilled or well versed in anything; a proficient
example: adepts in philosophy

definition: To stick fast or cleave, as a glutinous substance does; to become joined or united.
example: wax adhered to his finger

definition: Something that lies next to something else, especially the side of a right triangle that is neither the hypotenuse nor the opposite.
example: The word adjacent is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: To warn or notify of a fault; to reprove gently or kindly, but seriously; to exhort.
example: The word admonish is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Adornment
example: The word adorn is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Deft, dexterous, or skillful.
example: The word adroit is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Flattery; fulsome praise.
example: He was uncomfortable with the adulation from his fans.

definition: To corrupt.
example: The word adulterate is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: An opponent or rival.
example: He prepared to fight his adversary.

definition: Unfavorable; antagonistic in purpose or effect; hostile; actively opposing one's interests or wishes; contrary to one's welfare; acting against; working in an opposing direction.
example: adverse criticism

definition: Someone whose job is to speak for someone's case in a court of law; a counsel.
example: The word advocate is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: The study of art or beauty.
example: The word aesthetic is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Receiving others kindly and conversing with them in a free and friendly manner; friendly, courteous, sociable.
example: The word affable is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: An attempt to assume or exhibit what is not natural or real; false display; artificial show.
example: The word affectation is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Somebody who is wealthy.
example: The word affluent is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: To make great; to enlarge; to increase.
example: to aggrandize one's authority, distress

definition: A mass, assemblage, or sum of particulars; something consisting of elements but considered as a whole.
example: The word aggregate is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Having the faculty of quick motion in the limbs; apt or ready to move
example: an agile creature

definition: A person who holds to a form of agnosticism, especially uncertainty of the existence of a deity.
example: The word agnostic is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Eagerness; liveliness; enthusiasm.
example: The word alacrity is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Although, despite (it) being.
example: The word albeit is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: The ancient search for a universal panacea, and of the philosopher's stone, that eventually developed into chemistry.
example: The word alchemy is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: A stranger; an alien.
example: The word alienate is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Alleviation; abatement; check.
example: The word allay is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: The representation of abstract principles by characters or figures.
example: The word allegory is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: To make less severe, as a pain or difficulty.
example: Alcohol is often a cheap tool to alleviate the stress of a hard day.

definition: To set aside for a purpose.
example: The word allocate is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: A metal that is a combination of two or more elements, at least one of which is a metal.
example: The word alloy is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: To refer to something indirectly or by suggestion.
example: The word allude is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: The power to attract, entice; the quality causing attraction.
example: The word allure is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Regard for others, both natural and moral without regard for oneself; devotion to the interests of others; brotherly kindness.
example: The word altruism is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: To merge, to combine, to blend, to join.
example: to amalgamate one race with another

definition: Open to multiple interpretations.
example: The politician was criticized for his ambiguous statements and lack of precision.

definition: Simultaneously experiencing or expressing opposing or contradictory feelings, beliefs, or motivations.
example: The word ambivalent is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: To make better, or improve, something perceived to be in a negative condition.
example: They offered some compromises in an effort to ameliorate the situation.

definition: Willing to respond to persuasion or suggestions.
example: The word amenable is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Friendly; kind; sweet; gracious
example: amiable ideas

definition: Showing friendliness or goodwill.
example: He was an amicable fellow with an easy smile.

definition: Lacking a definite form or clear shape.
example: The enormous pile of spaghetti landed on the floor in an amorphous heap.

definition: Large; great in size, extent, capacity, or bulk; for example spacious, roomy or widely extended.
example: an ample house

definition: A chronological mistake; the erroneous dating of an event, circumstance, or object.
example: The word anachronism is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Having analogy; corresponding to something else; bearing some resemblance or proportion (often followed by "to".)
example: The word analogous is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: The state of a society being without authorities or an authoritative governing body.
example: The word anarchy is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: A ban or curse pronounced with religious solemnity by ecclesiastical authority, often accompanied by excommunication; something denounced as accursed.
example: The word anathema is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Something that serves an ancillary function, such as an easel for a painter.
example: The word ancillary is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Violent hatred leading to active opposition; active enmity; energetic dislike.
example: The word animosity is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: An addition, an extension.
example: The word annex is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: To add annotation to.
example: The word annotate is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: A deviation from a rule or from what is regarded as normal; an outlier.
example: The word anomaly is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: To work against; to oppose (especially to incite reaction)
example: The other children constantly antagonized Joe to the point of tears.

definition: Any thing that precedes another thing, especially the cause of the second thing.
example: The word antecedent is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: A feeling of dislike (normally towards someone, less often towards something); repugnance or distaste.
example: The word antipathy is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Old-fashioned, out of date
example: The word antiquated is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: A proposition that is the diametric opposite of some other proposition.
example: The word antithesis is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Lack of emotion or motivation; lack of interest or enthusiasm towards something; disinterest (in something).
example: The word apathy is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Conical priest cap
example: The word apex is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Self-confidence; poise; composure.
example: His nonchalance and aplomb during hard times have always been his best character trait.

definition: Of, or pertaining to, the Apocrypha.
example: The word apocryphal is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: To make quiet; to calm; to reduce to a state of peace; to dispel (anger or hatred).
example: to appease the tumult of the ocean

definition: Anticipating something with anxiety or fear.
example: The word apprehensive is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Anything arbitrary, such as an arithmetical value or a fee.
example: The word arbitrary is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Understood by only a few.
example: arcane rituals

definition: (usually capitalized) A general term for the prehistoric period intermediate between the earliest period (‘Paleo-Indian’, ‘Paleo-American’, ‘American‐paleolithic’, &c.) of human presence in the Western Hemisphere, and the most recent prehistoric period (‘Woodland’, etc.).
example: The word archaic is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Full of ardor; fervent, passionate.
example: The word ardent is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Needing or using up much energy; testing powers of endurance.
example: The movement towards a peaceful settlement has been a long and arduous political struggle.

definition: Very dry.
example: The cake was arid.

definition: An animal of the subkingdom Articulata.
example: The word articulate is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: One who is devoted to the practice of self-denial, either through seclusion or stringent abstinence.
example: The word ascetic is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: An attack on somebody's reputation or good name, often in the phrase to cast aspersions upon….
example: The word aspersion is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: To attack with harsh words or violent force (also figuratively).
example: Muggers assailed them as they entered an alley.

definition: Agreement; act of agreeing
example: I will give this act my assent.

definition: An assertion; a section of source code which tests whether an expected condition is true.
example: The word assert is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: Hard-working, diligent or regular (in attendance or work); industrious.
example: The word assiduous is commonly used in academic contexts.

definition: To lessen the intensity of, to mitigate or relieve (hunger, emotion, pain etc.).
example: The word assuage is commonly used in academic contexts.
